description: Mjölnir, the legendary hammer of Thor.  It is rumored to be able to level mountains with a single blow.  You feel the power of Asgard coursing through the hammer.
Gungnir, the spear of Odin.  It is rumored to be the perfect spear, perfectly hitting any target regardless of the wielder's strength or skill.  If feels like Odin's protecting you.
Gram, the sword of Sigurd.  It is rumored to be the sword that slayed the legendary dragon, Fafnir.  Once said to have cleaved Regin's anvil in half, the edge is impeccable.
Laevateinn, the staff of Loki.  Said to have been plucked from the gates of Hel by Loki.  Imbued with a mysterious magic, the magic of the trickster god himself.

A variant of the combat knife that is made of orichalcum instead of steel.  Sharper and easier to maintain than steel while just as dense, this knife also has a thinner blade, which shaves off some weight.

A variant of the longsword that is made of orichalcum instead of steel.  Sharper and easier to maintain than steel while just as dense, this longsword also has a thinner blade, which shaves off some weight.
A fire axe made with orichalcum instead of steel.  This makes it possible to chop through harder materials, and in the very well-funded fire stations is preferred.

A variant of the longsword that is made of dragonbone.  This makes for a very powerful blade without sacrificing durability.  Even better than orichalcum, and you can sense that this isn't even its final form.

A variant of the battleaxe that is made of dragonbone.  This makes for a very powerful blade without sacrificing durability.  Even better than orichalcum, and you can sense that this isn't even its final form.

A variant of the qiang that is made of dragonbone.  This makes for a very powerful blade without sacrificing durability.  Even better than orichalcum, and you can sense that this isn't even its final form.

A variant of the tachi that is made of dragonbone.  This makes for a very powerful blade without sacrificing durability.  Even better than orichalcum, and you can sense that this isn't even its final form.
